author: zimmer62

title: HI-SEAS Analog Mars Habitat - Martian Dome
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Print your very own Martian habitat! HI-SEAS (Hawai’i Space Exploration Analog and Simulation) is a long duration analog Mars mission. HI-SEAS.org. I'm a crew member of mission III which began October 15, 2014 and will end June 13, 2015 The main purpose of the mission is to help understand how crew members interact when living and working together during long duration, isolated missions (like a mission to Mars) as well as how to select crew members for such missions. As such we have no live contact with the outside world, we eat shelf stable food and wear simulated space suits whenever we leave the habitat. In addition to the main study there are a number of opportunistic studies going on as well. They are focused on either psychology, group dynamics or some combination of the two. Generally they involve some kind of task or game and filling out surveys about our mood and interactions with other crew members. In total there are about 40 tasks per week for these six studies. On top of those, we all have our own individual research areas as well. I’m looking at the utility of 3D printing in Mars missions/in isolated environments. For more info see my blog at https://www.almostmars.com
Other people’s research areas and blogs are:
Martha – indoor gardening - https://martianadventures.wordpress.com/
Jocelyn – looking at cortisol/stress levels and correlating it exercise, sleep, eating habits, etc. -http://fivestarview.blogspot.com/
Sophie – Robotics - https://domesoph.wordpress.com/
Neil – gut/skin microbiome
Allen – looking at Earth-Mars transfer orbits About the Habitat:
The HI-SEAS Habitat is located at approximately 8000 ft elevation on the northern slope of Mauna Loa. The habitat, based on a dome supplied by Pacific Domes International with internal two-story structure designed by V. Paul Ponthieux of Envision Design, was built by the Blue Planet Foundation of Honolulu, Hawaii. The geodesic dome is 36 feet in diameter, enclosing a volume of 13,570 cubic feet. The ground floor has an area of 993 square feet (878 square feet usable) and includes common areas such as kitchen, dining, bathroom with shower, lab, exercise, and common spaces. The second floor loft spans an area of 424 square feet and includes six separate staterooms and a half bath. In addition, a 160 square foot workshop converted from a 20-foot high steel shipping container is attached to the habitat.

I've been printing at a 1:200 scale but scale as you see fit.  
I've been printing default setting on my Up Mini, .25mm layers. Support for less than 30deg.

description.text:
Welcome to FrankenForge! I know this is a very beefy extruder, but I don't understand why everyone wants to make these as tiny and thing as possible. I want strong and long-lasting as it's getting moved off the head regardless. This is being designed with a PowerSpec 3D Pro / Flashforge Dual in mind, but should work with any 1.75mm filament printer. Parts List Printed (Make sure you print both Left or both Right parts)
Idler x1
base x1 Other
M3 40mm Sockethead Bolt x1
M3 15mm Sockethead Bolt x1
M3 6mm Flathead Socket Bolt x1
M3 30mm Sockethead Bolt x2
608 Berring x1
12mm x 1mm Washer x2
M3 Flat Washer x1
M5 Threaded Bowden Fitting x2
M5 Nut x2

This uses the M5 bowden connectors from B3 Innovations (http://www.b3innovations.com) and appropriate nuts to hold them in place (I hate screwing into plastic, even with a proper tap and die threading) and sit into the extruder for stability.

description.text:
This object is a combination of Phaux's Mushroom iPhone Dock part A: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1569
and
EFFALO' Strut Cap from his dome kit: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7017' It creates a fun desktop item that relieves stress! Thanks to Phaux and Effalo for their original models.

Print one Mushroom iPhone Dock Part A.  Try to make this a few fun colors.
Print three Strut Caps.  Put the strut caps into their seats in the Mushroom cap rollercoaster car.  You may need to sand the ends of the strut caps to fit.
Draw a simple face on each of the strut caps with a Sharpee marker.  One smiley, one flat, and one frowny!
Marvel at the simplicity of this juxtaposition, and drive it around your desk and feel the relief it brings. You can also put it on top of your filament spool, and watch them spin!

author: VanAllesWatOntwerp

description.text:
If you have an Epson printer with a genuine Epson CISS system (I think currently that means an L455, L850, L1300, L1800, L800, L300, L350, L355 or an L555) then you are likely to be buying genuine Epson ink bottles. This is a great system with one flaw. Once the bottles have been opened they are not very secure. I have had one fall over and leak all over my drawer. So I made this.  
Initially I just made the base and it holds the bottles so securely that it's all you really need. But I then decided to create a cover to stop other things in my drawer from touching the bottles. Then I added an alternative cover (tapered) just because I like the look of it. Take your pick.  
It's a big print but worth it.

description.text:
From the depths of the red planet comes UFO-01 with its infinitely advanced menace! You may run for the hills, but you cannot escape!  
This is the first of a series of retro flying saucers that I intend to make which incorporate the use of vending machine bubble capsules. These make perfect clear domes for retro flying saucers.  
This one was printed using silver ABS and transparent red PLA. You can use your own materials.  
Stay tuned. It is my intention to make this a modular system with different tops, bottoms, legs, and even something under the dome eventually.  
Enjoy.

Print as-is. Use whatever colors you like. Then pop a small vending machine bubble capsule into the top.  
Note that cleanup of the landing gear can be delicate. Small parts. But the legs slot in nicely. I use Krazy Glue to assemble.  
The pegs are to align the top and bottom halves.  
Good luck.

author: Sazabi

description.text:
[My website: http://jlu227.wix.com/kay-lu
Hi visitors!
Since I am developing my website currently, I encourage you to visit my website and leave comments there! <3 :) ] Finally this project is done!
I call it "Surprise Box". The Box I created has several layers.
The lower layer is used to hide Arduino and battery. I also make a hold at the bottom of the heart, in order for a LED light to go in.
The Arduino part of my project, I used a PIR sensor, so when people approach the box or when people open it, the heart will be light up. Another thing is the "fence" that's built inside the box by a wall of hexagons, which created an empty space inside, was supposed to be used for planting. My original idea was to plant some moss in the box as a background. However, I haven't found moss to plant there yet, so I used some dry pine tree leaves instead. Meaning
The meaning behind my "Surprise Box" project, except from making whoever receives the box surprised/happy, also symbolizes my view of protecting the environment:
During my environmental volunteering trip this semester, I was surprised by how ignorant people could be and don't think that our action can actually have influence on the environment.
And the plant/ moss part of the project conveys my idea that personally, I think plants have "hearts", or their feelings too. So when people cut a tree, it can feel the pain. The flowers on the heart and the butterfly symbolize the beauty and purity of the nature. The nature provides all these enjoyable sceneries to all the livings in this world, and they are something that we human need to treasure and protect.
I used SLS to print it. The powder I used is PA2200, which is a Nylon material, water resistant.

https://www.youtube.com/embed/TDfLqazCupo This is not The Greatest UM2 Clone, no.
This is just a tribute. This project began as a fun way to learn AutoDesk Fusion 360. I started by importing the entire Solidworks CAD file into a new Fusion 360 project, dropped the frame (walls) from the printer, built 20x20 Misumi aluminum extrusions to wrap the printer guts and then worked to build brackets to support all the parts that previously attached to the frame. I've been printing nonstop on this new printer with the same precision and quality as my real UM2. In fact, I can use the same GCODE in either machine with identical results. A360 Source Download Link - Use this link to download a copy of the source (in your CAD flavor).

The BOM - Click here The prices in the BOM are most likely out of date. Use the links in the BOM to find the parts. I had good experiences with all of the sellers I dealt with and found the parts to be close-to if not identical to official parts. This includes the 1.75mm version of the UM2 nozzle/heatblock. The BOM has a breakdown to buy all the parts to build the Z-axis platform/heated bed or to buy the official UM2 heated bed kit (which is actually intended for the UMO+). The cost of getting the kit is only $15 more when you calculate the PSU and lead screw Z-axis motor. There's also a small electronics board which acts as a relay for powering the heaterboard with the 24PSU and outputing 19V for the UMO. It's not needed, but an added bonus for a future project. :-) The kit is going to be easier... but it depends on how patient and adventurous you are.
Build Instructions - Click Here Please refer to the official Ultimaker 2 assembly instructions for assembling the gantry and print head.

My printer is using 1/4" acrylic that I bought from Lowes and cut on a 20x12 laser cutter. I sanded the underside to create a frosted look. I would have cut it as a single piece but the laser cutter was just a tad too small. This is why it's 2 pieces joined with 3D printed connectors and screws. I have included the CorelDraw file and the floor connectors.

• Updated all Gantry parts to adjust tolerances for bearing fitment. After assembling another printer, I've found that they needed a .1mm increase.
  • Updated Y-Axis Motor Mount to allow for room of the belt.
  • Updated X-Axis Motor Mount to allow for screw space
    • New files all have _v2 prefix. Deprecated files were moved to a file called "deprecated_v1.zip.

comments.author: Adrian_antoniw

comments.text:
Go to Misumi and search for PSFJ6, PSFJ8, and PSFJ12. These are the part numbers for the three different diameter trades. The last number of the part number is the diameter of the rod.
These are the measurements for what you need to order.
X-linear shaft diameter:8mm length:337mm --- 2pcs
Y-linear shaft diameter:8mm length:348mm --- 2pcs
Z-linear shaft diameter:12mm length:339mm --- 2pcs
Print Head shaft X/Y diameter:6 mm length:320mm --- 1pc
Print Head shaft X/Y diameter:6 mm length:300mm --- 1pc
I built my printer two years ago with cheap aliexpress rods. A few months ago I ordered the Misumi rods for $70 when I rebuilt my printer. Totally worth it.

Thanks for this great printer.
I have some troubles with the 2 hotend Fans connected to the fan PWM, they wont Start turning, only if i help them to Start. But i think they are turning to slow. If fanspeed is set 0% i messure ~24 V , when it set to 100% i messure ~19V. Is this normal, or is my board Broken?
comments.author: err0r3o3

comments.text: Yeah, it sounds like you killed the PWM circuit for the fans. While it sucks, you can just use the second hotend output on the board (and change the pin in the firmware) to resolve the problem. That PWM circuit is super delicate and you can kill it so easily. I've killed 2 of them myself.... and that was being mostly careful  :-p
comments.author: err0r3o3

comments.text: Hey so I'm looking for some advice. I built a UM2 clone and I've installed the new UM2+ feeder but I'm still using the original stepper motor. I was wondering has anyone done that and what settings did you change for it to work properly? Thanks in advance.
comments.author: NitroTech

comments.text: The UM2 feeder used a 0.9 degree step angle with the reasoning that they provide more torque.  So you just need to figure out if the new UM2+ extruder motor is 0.9 or 1.8 step angle.  Either will work, it's just a matter of changing a value in the firmware related to the STEPS per revolution.
comments.author: NitroTech

comments.text: Yeah, so I thought I came across that the stock extruder motor runs at 282 steps, I've tried doubling that. I was hoping someone may have already done the leg work and found what steps work best.

A bracket for the little tab that switches the printhead nozzles will be the only thing that has to be designed and installed to the aluminum extrusion. I could be completely wrong, the printhead may require the UM3 mainboard to be completely functional. Either way I am going to do research as the information comes out to figure out if this is possible. My build is still going strong!

comments.text: Hey I just wanted to share something. I purchased a UM2 set of smooth rods from Ali Express and unfortunately some of them were of unusable quality. The seller is shipping me replacements but I got impatient and ordered the 8mm and 6mm smooth rods from Misumi. I just received them today and they are absolutely amazing. This UM2 Clone is the second printer build for me and so far nothing compares to these linear rods from Misumi. I didn't order the 12mm rods because the ones from China are usable. The price difference really isn't that crazy either. If I could change one thing about what I have purchased for this build, I would source the rods from Misumi. The linear shafts are really one of the most important parts of the printer. I've said enough about the shafts. Awesome design Jason and thank you for trying to make this as affordable as you can without sacrifice to quality. I'm starting to realize just how much work it is to plan something like this from square one and hope I can design something of this magnitude some day.

comments.text:
Jason,
My build is almost finished. Hey what is supposed to contact the z axis limit switch?
comments.author: SK-Polymer

comments.text: Assuming you have the official ultimaker bed assembly, get a M3 screw that you have leftover, I used a 30mm I believe. Using two M3 nuts, put the screw through the matching hole at the back of the bed plate and adjust the nuts until you get the right length of the screw to make contact with the limit switch. Good luck!
comments.author: SK-Polymer

comments.text: The hole in my build plate is way off from the location of the switch. I would have to either 1. add standoffs to switch and drill hole in acrylic floor for contact screw (not ideal) or 2. drill a new hole in the build plate. I think ill just drill a hole in the plate. lol

comments.text: The problem here is that they changed the mounting holes on the aluminum platform so it could be generically used in all UM2 flavors (extended, regular, go, etc). The previous version had the correct hole.

The main problem is that when doing the initial bed leveling wizard, the print head moves to the front center of the bed instead of the back center. Any suggestions would help. Thank you in advance.
comments.author: Sarchopilus

comments.text: Yeah, so you have your Y motors backwards. The most simplest way to resolve this is to simply flip the plug, so if the colors were (RGBW) they would now be (WBGR) viewing the plug from the same angle.  The problem is that the UM2 mainboard uses plugs that can't just be flipped. So instead of doing that, you just have to go into the firmware Configuration.h and find this:
comments.author: Sarchopilus

comments.text: Ok so I changed #define INVERT_Y_DIR false to #define INVERT_Y_DIR true. When I did that upon starting the bed leveling the print head started moving to the front of the printer and spazzed out there because it couldn't find the limit switch. to fix that I had to change #define Y_HOME_DIR 1 to #define Y_HOME_DIR -1. Now everything seems to be in the correct orientation but it is not moving to the front of the print bed after doing the back adjustment location. I checked the bed size and it is showing #define X_MAX_POS 230 #define X_MIN_POS 0 #define Y_MAX_POS 224.5 #define Y_MIN_POS 0 #define Z_MAX_POS 230 #define Z_MIN_POS 0 (sorry not sure how to do the format you did jason. Here is a short video of how it is work now. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5dWxwAUym7A&feature=youtu.be
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: It looks like the homing is correct, going to the back left corner, hitting both X/Y limit switches.  You are correct that the Y_HOME_DIR is reversed.  I made the assumption you took the settings from the UM2 Marlin Configuration.
comments.author: Sarchopilus

Ultimaker modified their bed platform so that it works with their full line of UM2 versions now, so some of the screw holes were moved/changed.... comments.text: Well, I thought I'd update my progress with my non-working printhead fans. I performed some ohm tests on T1 transistor, compared to T2. I found notable differences and decided to change out the suspect transistor. T1 transistor is part of the circuit that feeds FAN PWM.  Those transistors are tiny, super tiny but I managed to get a new one soldered in. I also swapped out the original Sunon fans for original Ultimaker fans. I suspect the Sunon fans burnt up the transistor.
comments.author: NitroTech

comments.text: I'd stick with the hardened and chromed rods. After hundreds, or even thousands of hours printing, and possibly millions of separate movements I would be worried about anything else holding up. I actually had to get two rods replaced because they were bent and the aliexpress seller was quick to send me new ones. Since they aren't too expensive, and really are the heart of the machine, I ended up ordering three complete sets and and using the straightest of the bunch. Now I have spares. comments.text: The bearings should have the 8mm spacers (varied lengths, depending on axis). Pushed against those spacers are the outer bearing and the pulleys. The pulleys should be tightened against the spacers/bearing, locking the rods in place. This must be down on all 8 corners (X + Y).

comments.author: ddutch13

comments.text: 2x24v is not correct either. The spec calls for 2x12v fans, run in series (not parallel). It is possible that running 2x24v fans in parallel, you drew twice as many amps then was expected and it blew out the PWM.  Buying the board direct from UM won't protect against bad wiring unfortunately. The PWM circuit is sensitive to over amps being pulled through it.  The UM forums have plenty of discussions about this.

comments.text:
Let me look at it and try to remember.
If you are planning on printing the fan shroud for the hotend, you need 8x M3x14mm screws to hold the fans on.
If you print the fan shroud yourself, then search amazon for "high temperature tape" to put around the area where the hotend goes.
Also, I think this design assumed that the limit switches have threads in them, but the limit switches I got were not threaded, so for the Y axis I had to design my own custom bracket to hold that in the correct place.
And if you are going to print the extruder bracket that goes on the extruder motor, you will need the screws and spring for that. I just bought an aluminum one because it came with all the parts.
comments.author: wenyi189

comments.text: I think the heating cartridge takes at least few amps of current. In this case I am pretty sure you don't want to use a single cat 5 wire for the heating cartridge. It might work, but even though I doubt it will heat up fast enough.
comments.author: DerpyEyed

comments.text: The heating cartridge and PT100 have their own cable that is plenty long enough to reach the board, so you don't need to connect those to the cat 5 cable.

comments.text: Yes. But the idea is that each pair is carrying it's own rail of current. I have not confirmed this, but my guess is that one rail is for the heatbed and one is for everything else.  So when wiring one up, you will want to make sure you're providing enough amps (and use heavy gauge wire).

There is a problem with the Motor Mount X-axis piece. The holes that connect it to the extrusion are too close to the side, and when you stick the screws through the holes they do not reach the center of the extrusion, and it can't be attached. If you sand away enough of the side to make it fit, the extrusion then blocks two of the screws for the motor from being able to go through.

Has anyone else had this problem? What is the fix?
comments.author: DerpyEyed

comments.text: I did have this issue I ended up adding about 1.75mm of material between the extrusion holes and the motor mount holes. But considering no one complained about it I thought it is how much my material shrank as I did modify some parts as well not to mention about 1.5mm spacer on all axis. Either that or I completely screwed the extrusion measurements (misumi)

comments.text: In my case, my material doesn't stretch, like, at all. So this makes it impossible for me to attach that piece. I'm not a designer, so I can't fix the model myself (I tried fixing it). I also tried using a drill to make the hole bigger, but that actually ruined the piece, so I have to make another one. Because of this, I'm now at a brick wall for this project and I can't continue unless it is fixed. I have tried every way I can think of to fix it myself, and all of them failed.

comments.author: lucap3600

comments.text: Yeah, anything using the Mega2650 will work. Just a matter of configuring Marlin to work with the way you have things wired up. (Configuration.h, Configuration_adv.h, and possibly pins.h). In Configuration.h, choose your board and most of the work will already be done as long as you use the ports as labeled on the board.  Otherwise, you may need to alter pins.h to match pin to particular functionality (fans, motors, heaters, etc).

comments.text:
Wondering, did anyone who bought the heated bed from Aliexpress,
Have it work correctly?
The right temp sensor and heats up to about 100 degrees for abs?
Thanks
comments.author: racerxx

comments.text:
The bed I bought from Aliexpress is 7 ohms resistance (whereas it should be around 3-3.5 ohms), it only gets to 60 degrees with 24V. I contacted a few eBay sellers and they all came back with the same resistance, so basically they are no good for this application unless you take the voltage up as alec220 did.
24 / 7 = 3.4 amps or 81 watts, whereas at 3.5 ohms it would be 24 /3.5 = 6.8 amps or 161 watts
comments.author: racerxx

comments.text: I bought a bed for Aliexpress. To make it work properly, I picked up the voltage on the power supply to 27.5 volts and put the leads twice the thickness (soldered in parallel even same wire). Now it is heated to 110 degrees Celsius for 15 minutes.
comments.author: racerxx

comments.text:
Hi Jason,
I actually have two PSUs. One powering the controller and motors and the other powering the heat bed. I attached the heat bed directly to the PSU and still have a temp issue.
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: Another thing to check (if you've got a multi-meter) is the resistance across the heat bed. Someone further down in the comments had the same issue as you, and found that his heat bed was measuring roughly 6 ohms instead of 3. Since I=V/R, with a resistance double what it should be you'll be getting half the amperage that you need.
comments.author: AlexVen

comments.text: Hmmmm... sounds like you're on top of things.  :-)   The only thing you didn't mention was if you tried a different PSU. Are the 2 you're using the same type/brand?  I still lean towards the PSU isn't putting out enough amps to get the bed above 80.
comments.author: AlexVen

comments.text: i'm about 90% through purchasing the components, and was wondering if it is worth trying a cheaper power supply and mounting it under the floor. Is this type of power supply suitable? Is there any reason I shouldn't go down this road?
comments.author: nickdav76

comments.text:
I did what you have suggested. I have a 24v 350W supply clipped to the side rails.
Hooking up the wires directly to the board is the hard part and as GayssianSphere suggested is probably not the best idea as it adds 2-3mm (depending on the wire gauge you are using) to the bottom of the board and this make the board extremely difficult to slide into the slot as designed.
I am trying to find a suitable plug and I'll change to the having the power wire come out of the machine and plug into the board as it was designed. Or my second option is to buy a clone of the Ultimaker power supply and mount it under the floor and then run the lead to the board as described above.
comments.author: nickdav76

comments.text: FYI, as an alternative last night I switched to an EZStruder setup for driving my 1.75mm filament. It was a pretty painless switch. Just changed the direction of the extruder motor in the marlin config file and then changed the e-steps to 94. So far it seems to feed my filament much more consistently. (but others may have better luck with the existing setup. Maybe I just had a weak spring)

comments.text: The EZStruder is a pretty nice extruder. I actually ripped one apart to get the Mk7 drive gear for my direct drive experiment. It's working out pretty well so far. However it needs a re-think/redesign as I'm losing some print area.

So I just move it up and pushed the bearing mounts to the left and back. I think if I ever get around to a version 2 i'm going to sacrifice some Z and move the bearings and hotend closer to the original UM2 position. I would take the CAD file and expose just the frame and things attached to the frame (except the bed)... then slice the entire thing down the center on both X and Y axis. comments.text: I think the photo just misrepresents the quality. The LEDs, camera flash and the macro lens really highlight the layers... You can tell by the large depth of field by using a large aperture under mostly low light. The black Yoda's finish is silky smooth and at 100 microns, you barely see the layers in normal (non-harsh) light. The blue Yoda has a bit of under extrusion, but that's because printing at 200 microns, you're pushing out 2 times the amount of plastic and I was printing too fast (and/or not hot enough) to push the plastic out consistently...

comments.author: LumberjackEngineering

comments.text: 46mm may be pushing it. I just checked with an extra 47mm I had laying around and it clears the heatbed for the Extruder, Z, and X axis... but NOT the Y Axis.. it clips the cover on the bed.  The cover is not necessary and will probably work then. You can always just get a single 40mm for the Y-axis.
comments.author: LumberjackEngineering

comments.text: Ah, awesome! Since I'm not buying the official heat bed kit I won't have the cover in the way anyways... I'll see how it works once I get it all put together and I'll go from there... I appreciate your help!
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text:
Try to visualize it with autodesk online to see if the nema 46mm will fit. I have also the same question : I want to reuse my MK2B heatbed to fit this printer 220 x 220. I think that we should buy/cut the ultimaker 2 aluminium plate that moves vertically on the Z axis. The point is that the official heatbed over the Z aluminium plate is also made of aluminium on one face (toward the glass). It means that we have to cut an aluminium part that makes the interface between the Z axis aluminium plate and our mk2b heatbed (with the correct holes on it).
The glass retaining clip will not fit in this case... because the Z axis aluminium plate is bigger than the mk2b heatbed and its glass.

comments.text: The printhead on Aliexpress can be ordered as 1.75 or 3mm filament. Depending on which one you buy, it will come with a PTFE coupler. Just add a comment in your order that says you want the 1.75 version...otherwise 3mm comes as default. The printhead comes assembled, so it's easy to see how it all fits together. The PTFE coupler has a slot for the PTFE tubing, depending on the filament size. It's 4mm OD for 1.75mm filament and 6mm OD for 3mm filament.

comments.text: Okay so here's the skinny... The UM2 uses 1.8 degree (200steps/mm) on the X/Y/Z motors... but a .9 (400steps/mm) for the extruder. I screwed up on the BOM and put a 1.8 degree stepper. I have not investigated why they do that... my  guess is possibly more control over extrusion w/more steps per mm.
comments.author: lions3

comments.text: Note to anyone looking at this. The UM2 motherboard saves the e-steps setting to eprom. So after running: M92 E180  in either Repetier or Pronterface MAKE SURE to save your settings to the eprom. Which is the command: M500
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: I think this matter of modify the firmawere will be a little dificult for my on my beginings. Could you explain more easily, something like for fool people how modify it?. I adquired a stepper motor of 1.8 degree like posted in your BOM. If I adquire another stepper motor of 0.9 degree (link below) I won´t need to modify nothing on the firmaware??
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: Correct. That motor you linked to will work. Just keep in mind that the 1.8 degree motors in the BOM are 40mm in length. This one is 48mm in length. When mounted, it looks like it should clear the default heated bed/plate w/o an issue.
comments.author: morfeushavana

comments.text: hahaha.. I knew it had to be something like that. I have a 1.8 motor and the standard knurled gear. My other printer, a Mendel90, also uses a 1.8 for a direct drive extruder and i've never had any issues. So maybe 0.9 is really only needed for larger filament. As the diameter is larger and it moves slower. Thus needing more steps.
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: Help. I need either 12 or 24v from the motherboard for my E3D fan. (I have both a 12v and a 24v fan sitting on my desk). Anyone know what pins I can use?
comments.author: lions3

comments.text: Okay, yeah.... at the FRONT of the board (to the right of the big blue relay and above the screw terminal ports) is a 2-pin 24v output. It could run a fan w/o issue. It's an always on output, so it can't control it via G codes. If you wanted/needed to, use the 2nd screw terminal (heater 2, I think).... you can access that pin via gcode to turn on/off during printing... which is something I may change on mine at some point.

comments.text: There are two "accessory" 24V outputs on the UM2 board. One of them is at the corner between the relay and power inlet. The other is at the back of the board and is labeled "Fan 19-24v".
comments.author: hugsy

comments.text: How extrusions are connected? Only using printed parts?
comments.author: pikey

comments.text: Yes they are. It's rock solid.  You could also use the suggestions from user "misan" in the comments. Search the comments for "L joints".
comments.author: pikey

comments.text: The BOM has been updated to reflect the cheaper post-assembly nuts via China and deprecated the Misumi nuts. This was purely done to lower the cost of the build. The cost for these nuts when from $56 to $11 (excluding shipping). That's $45 that can be spent on some new filament!  ;-)
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: I bought theses http://www.robotdigg.com/product/317/Pre+Assembly+T+Nuts+for+2020+Aluminum+Extrusion. They are cheap and well made ! Unfortuneatly, I ordered the M5 instead of the M3 you used, so I have to redesign all your printed parts to drill bigger holes :o(
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: Wow, love this project. I spent all last evening researching if this is something I might like building for a 2nd printer. Have you printing with ABS yet? I could see myself laser cutting a full enclosure.
comments.author: lions3

comments.text: And on the topic of ABS, yes it prints wonderfully in ABS. Most of my prints have been smaller, hand-held parts... so I haven't had to worry about curling/lifting with an open case.
comments.author: lions3

comments.text: Are there any issues with enclosing the sides? Won't the heatbed cables get in the way? I'm keen to build this as an upgrade to my  i3, but a (semi) enclosed case is a must.
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: That cover comes with the Ultimaker Heated Bed upgrade kit. It's lasercut from wood. I stained it black.
comments.author: lions3

comments.text: Really nice work and well detailled instructions Jason ! I'm actually buidling it and I'd like to add some modifications:
comments.author: hugsy

comments.text: $300 is a bit steep... I totally agree... BUT, I will say this.... after having several other printers w/various types of beds w/various leveling procedures, once I used the UM2 for the first time, I was sold. It is, hands down, the easiest bed to deal with.  I have never bothered to go down the "auto-level" route w/the UM2 bed because it takes about 30 seconds to level and I never have to touch it again unless I have done maintenance to the print head.
comments.author: hugsy

comments.text: Thanks for these informations, very usefull ! I never tried any other bed and I had no idea this one was so robust... I think I will follow your design then. About the power supply, I see in your BOM that the heater bed kit includes a 24V 9.2A PSU, so there are 2 power supplies (one for the printer and another for the bed) ? I can't see the other one you use in the BOM... Does the original UM2 have a single power supply for everything ?
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: Yes, it is 1 PSU for everything.  The reason that the PSU is included in the heatbed kit is that it's meant for UM 1 owners who will replace their current 19v PSU w/the 24v one. The kit comes with an adapter board for stepping down the power to 19v for the UMO.... but you won't need that board (SAVE it for another project!) for a UM2 build.
comments.author: hugsy

comments.text: I believe the thing files / stl's are missing the lcd controller knob.
comments.author: goopyplastic

comments.text: I have attached the knob. It wasn't originally added because it needed to be redesigned to prevent the click-encoder's stem from being over-stressed.
comments.author: goopyplastic

comments.text: I just updated the BOM to point to fbrc8.com for the heated bed upgrade. They are the US distributor for Ultimaker... AND the price is $30 cheaper than MakerShed... PLUS, they are offering free shipping via UPS Ground.
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: Can you please elaborate more on the BOM, I want to make sure I am understanding this correctly. I can either build my own heated bed (UM2 part-by-part) for 210 minus the threaded rod, psu and 4 pin connector or I can buy the heatbed (um2 upgrade kit (though it says for UM original on the link)) for $350 and still have to buy the lead screw psu and limit switch (long arm)
comments.author: HerrVan

comments.text: No, the heated bed kit comes with:  Nema 17 w/lead screw, limit switch, glass plate, 24v psu. So if you get the kit, you have everything you need. If you do the "part-by-part" option and get those additional pieces on your own, you end up spending $15 (and that's not accounting for shipping -- although lots of parts ship for free, you're guaranteed to spend at least $15 is shipping for some of those parts).... so tl;dr is JUST by the kit. It's very reasonably priced for all the parts you get in the kit....
comments.author: HerrVan

comments.text: Also the HNTT5-3 Nuts come in around $65 for 2, could it possibly be HNTT5SN5-3 that come out to be $28 a piece or $56?
comments.author: HerrVan

comments.text: That package price (100x) is $28 * 2 = 56.  The price of those nuts are RIDICULOUS. It's been my biggest issue with the cost of building the printer.
comments.author: HerrVan

comments.text: did you have any luck with these cheaper HNTT5-3 nuts?
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: I just got in some post-assembly nuts in (as opposed to the pre-assembly nuts we've been discussing) and they're great. The difference between the 2 types is that the post-assembly version is designed to drop into the extrusion's slot and twist into place. While the pre-assembly nuts have more mass/strength, I don't see that being a concern for our purposes.... PLUS, these post-assembly nuts will keep you from pulling out your hair when you forget to add a nut during assembly.
comments.author: lions3

comments.text: So is the nut in BOM right now post-assembly or pre-assembly? It looks like I can drop it into the extrusions and twist, but I wanna confirm this with you. thanks.
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: You are free to use either post or pre. I found that while building out the frame, it's easier to work with the pre-assembly nuts. It's great to have post-assembly after the fact so you can add things w/o disassembling anything.
comments.author: wenyi189

comments.text: Thank you for you clarification. For now I am going to just use the nuts in the BOM. I should have all the parts by a week or two. It took me more than a week to print the parts (includes reprint). Oh man, I have no idea what I am going to face lol.
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: Haha. Course I just ordered the other version last week.
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: Yeah. The dimensions are mostly identical but w/o a nice nickel finish and the tiny raised bumps on the flat section that is meant to act as anti-slip assistance.  I didn't check all 100 nuts, but I found a couple nuts that had bad treads and I couldn't get an m3 screw thru it. I need to go thru the full 100 and confirm if it's just a couple or many that have this quality issue.  My guess is that the seller will make it right.
comments.author: lions3

comments.text: Really awesome work! I will add I believe the um2 uses a .9 degree stepper and not a 1.8 in your bom, robotdigg has .9 steppers so maybe just change the part listed.
comments.author: goopyplastic

comments.text: Only the extruder has a 400steps/rev stepper on the UM2
comments.author: goopyplastic

comments.text:
Hi, i was messing with the model (amazing work by the way) and i notice that
the length of the z axis linear rod was 331mm. But the spec for the um2 is 339mm.
I was wondering if there was any fit up issues when the printer was built?
Thanks for you help
comments.author: racerxx

comments.text: Oh YEAH! THAT was the other thing that I meant (but forgot) to fix before sending out the model/STLs... when I was ordering parts for the machine, I had a lot of long 8mm rods (which came from my disassembled Rostock delta printer). I cut those to size instead of buying pre-cut rods. So instead of buying the rod kits from China, I ended up buying 12mm 13" long (330.2 mm) rods from VXB.com, in the US. And then I altered the design.
comments.author: racerxx

comments.text:
Thanks for the reply. Is a possible option, just to length the vertical alum extrusion 8 mm?
That way, everything basically stays the same.
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: I've added updates to handle the 339mm Z axis linear rods. The parts are called Gantry_Z-Axis_Top_339mm.stl and Gantry_Z-Axis_Bottom_339mm.stl
comments.author: racerxx

comments.text: So just be clear I want to use these instead of the z-axis top and z-axis bottom from the old zip file?
comments.author: jasonatepaint

comments.text: Yes.  If you use the UM2 Z-axis rods that are 339mm.
comments.author: HerrVan

comments.text: You don't need to. 4mm on both top and bottom can be carved out to allow the 339mm to fit between the top and bottom z axis gantry brackets.
comments.author: racerxx

comments.text: Great work you did there. I've started printing the parts for the printer, but found out that the holes on the Z-axis top/bottom is tough to get the 12mm rod in. Again thanks for the hard work.
comments.author: AlphaZulu

comments.text: Thanks.
comments.author: AlphaZulu

comments.text: Thanks, I'll try that.

comments.text: Great work!!!!

comments.text: Hello! This is a fantastic idea and I'm planning to build it. I have a question regarding the printhead wiring harness. I didn't see anything on it in the instructions, so where did you source the connectors and wiring? Thanks!
comments.author: NitroTech

comments.text: Another good find of something I forgot to add to the BOM.  The connectors that the UM2 electronics uses are called JST-XHP series. You need them for the motors, 25mm fan, and the endstops. The other 2-pin connectors I used .1" 1x2 crimp connectors that I had from other arduino projects.

This is a tangent ogive nose cone for a high powered model rocket. Dimensions: Outer Diameter: 4 in
Lip diameter: 4.125 in
Shoulder height: 2 in
Total height: 7.2 in
Mass: ~85g (assuming ABS -- mass will vary)

Made using SolidWorks  
In my opinion, the best way to do parachute retention with this nosecone is to epoxy in a long threaded rod at the tip of the nosecone and attach the retention cord to there. This allows you to slide extra weight on if your rocket has stability issues or for use on multiple rockets.

author: Moe_Fpv_Team

description.text:
A customisable V idler pulley.  
I needed an idler pulley for fishing line that moved quite quickly. I could only find U and flat idler pulleys, which tend to let the fishing line wander out too easily, so I made this V pulley which works nicely.

Add the height and OD you need for the pulley.  
Add in the dimensions of the bearing. It will automatically add the correct support for it, so the bearing is centred in the pulley. The default settings are for a 608zz bearing.  
The Groove depth is distance from the edge of the pulley to the bottom of the V.  
Press the bearing in immediately after it finishes printing; the plastic will be softer and the ABS won't have shrunk completely.  
For some reason, the Thingiverse preview doesn't render it correctly for some settings and angles, however it will render both the image for your file and the STL file correctly.  
If anyone has any idea why this is happening then please leave a message!

NOTE: This is an adaptation of thing 18727 originally made by Boogie, who deserves the credit.
I have attached three different versions for an Iphone, Ipod Touch and an Android which vary according to where the camera lens is located. These were made to fit on a Bausch and Lomb stereo microscope.
While these are technically not a new design, I wanted to share my results and thoughts with anyone who is working on an adapter, and I know there are many.
Microscopes vary from one another, so the first adaptation you need is the diameter of the eyepiece.
Second, depending on the make and model of the scope, you need to determine the optimum distance between the camera and the eyepiece. I did this by simply holding the camera steady and measuring with a ruler the approximate distance that gave me a good clear image without the tunnel effect. This distance was the offset that I used on the adapter. Regardless of what you use for a camera, this distance won't change.
Using a diffuser filter (pictured) eliminated a halo effect from the light source that I was experiencing.
I don't have the capability of producing a parametric model, but if anyone has the time I think this would make a great addition to the open source lab tools. Every student has at least one of these camera devices, they can be printed very quickly and as you can see a pair of rubber bands is all that is needed to secure the camera.
Cheers

title: Public Building One
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
1:200 scale model for the refurbishment of an existing beachfront public building.  
Micro LED lighting was incorporated for extra impact on display.  
Please Note: Trees, vehicles, people model base and cover were not 3d printed.   
.STL files added by popular demand.

The building was modeled in Archicad, cleaned up with netfabb and printed on a Replicator 2 at standard default resolution.  
The 14 individual pieces allow the ability to remove roof and floor plates to view spaces below.  
Warning model is very large and takes a very long time to print, ignoring abortive sections.

remixed_from.author: alpharesearch
remixed_from.title: Makerslide end cap and filament feeder

description.text: Here is a space saving spool holder to clean up your desk / work bench.  Can be mounted on the ends of any Maker slide but it was designed for the Ord Bot.

I printed it with PLA at .25 layer height, 50% fill and support (seems sturdy but a little more fill might make you more comfortable). Hardware:
  • 13-14 inches of 1/4 inch threaded rod.
  • 4 x M5 16mm screws
  • 1/4 inch nuts and washers
  • 608ZZ bearings (optional)
  • Plastic Washers (optional)
    • 1) Print two spool holders (and optionally the washers)
    2) Tap the ends of the Makerslide with an M5 tap
    3) Mount the Spool holders with 4 x M5 screws
    4) Assemble the rod with the desired bearings (held with washers/nuts) at regular intervals (or without bearings with just washer/nuts at each end of rod) I've included large plastic washers that can be used as seperators. With 6 608zz bearings and 6 plastic washers, you can set up 3 spools perfectly spaced with this set-up.

comments.text: Does the spool rotate pretty freely without the bearings or do you recommend the bearings? Thanks
comments.author: runninfarmer

comments.text: It rotates pretty well without bearings and most extruders shouldn't have problems pulling the filament without the bearings but with the bearings it's very, very smooth.
comments.author: runninfarmer

comments.text: Very nice! This is exactly the kind of spool holder I've been looking for. I'd like to print this for my ORD bot but since I'm in Europe I'd like to use an 8mm rod (also fits the 608 bearings better). The insert at the top is just 1mm too narrow for this. Any chance you can upload the original file for modification?
comments.author: bjoerngiesler

comments.text: I'm sorry, the file I uploaded was the original file.  I started from an STL file that I modified in Blender3d.  So I did a quick mod and uploaded a version widening the top insert area by a little more than 1mm, I called it OrdBotSpoolHolder-8mm.  It says that the opening is a little more than 9mm so I hope it works for you.  If not, let me know and I'll open it up a little more.
comments.author: bjoerngiesler

comments.text: Very cool, that fits perfectly! Thanks a lot!
comments.author: blah_59

comments.text: My pleasure, no worries.
comments.author: bjoerngiesler

title: LaserCut Fairytale: Puppet Theater "Little Red Riding Hood"

description.text:
Upcycling-Project: Puppet Theater in A Drawer Make Your Own Stick Puppet Theater Take an old drawer and transform it into a little theater. All the puppets and the scenery can be put back into the drawer. And even the drawer itself can be put back into the cabinet. If you want you can make a whole fairytale cabinet.
The puppets and the scenery are cut out by a laser cutter. Every puppet consists of two views: one figure shows the front, the other one the side. Cut in a small gap and put the 2D figures together to create a 3-dimensional puppet.

Converting the Drawer into a Theater:
  • Disassemble an old wooden drawer. Pull out the base plate. Saw a part of. The part should be at least 15 cm wide - big enough to reach through the gap in the base plate. Then put the cropped base plate back into the drawer.
  • Screw four small eye bolts into the inside of the drawer. One eye bolt into each corner.
  • Measure your drawer and saw two wooden boards. These boards partition the drawer into three segments: I) Gap in the base plate for playing, II) Compartement for storing puppets and scenery, III) Compartement for tucking in the scenery. Attach the boards to the drawer with adhesive tape, nails or screws.
  • Cut two pieces of rope, e.g. nylon thread, that have the same lenght (about 1m). Tie the nylon threads to the eye bolts. Now you can suspend the theater everywhere you like.
    • Cutting the Puppets and the Scenery:
  • Measure the compartements of your drawer. The size of your Storage Compartement defines the maximum size of the puppets. The scenery can be cut in halfs or thirds in order to fit into the compartement.
  • Open the inkscape-file. Define the size of the figures as desired. Set a proper document size that corresponds to your laser cutter, too. Sometimes you have to rotate the figure 90° in order to fit onto your board. Set the proper stroke width (black, 0.01 mm).
    TIP: I made the figures out of cardboard, but I would recommend to use wood and to integrate the gap for sticking together the two figures into the inkscape-model. The gap has to be as wide as your wood is thick.
  • Let the laser cutter cut out the figures. Cut the scenery in half if it's too big. Joint it together simply via tape or with another kind of hinge-joint, so it can be folded together.
    • Stick the puppets together and tuck in the scenery. Have fun playing "Little Red Riding Hood".

title: World Blood Cancer Day logo keychain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Every year on May 28, blood cancer fighting organizations all around the world get together to launch massive donor typing and PR campaigns. They chose the red ampersand as their logo to remind everyone that "YOU & I = WE" are fighting diseases like blood cancer together and that anyone might someday rely on a hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
The WBCD motto is "make your mark" and the initiators are asking everyone to display the logo in any way they'd like - so I thought it just has to be 3D printed as well!
So print some of these keychains, give them to your friends and tell them about WBCD events in your area :-) more info:
http://www.dkms.de/en/worldbloodcancerday
http://www.deletebloodcancer.org/en

The writing is quite delicate, so you might have to upscale the model depending on your nozzle size.
I achieved the best results with my 0.5 mm nozzle by printing it upright, but the strength of the ring might suffer from this approach.

author: Stebo

description.text:
UPDATE
I have uploaded a new STL which has 2 main changes.
  • Stronger arm and longer tube grip - the original version flexed quite a lot and ultimately mine broke at the base of the arm
  • Slightly greater clearance below the arm to the large gear - I noticed that the gear was rubbing on the arm
    • The public onshape.com model has been updated. Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:766614 which did not fit the extruder heads on my TAZ 4, I have made this version. It fits the two heads I have and, at least visually, seems to significantly reduce the stress on the filament at the entry point. The design was created using onshape (http://onshape.com and I have made the design public there - just search "Lulzbot". If you would like the design in a more accessible format I can upload it in PARASOLID, ACIS, STEP IGES or SOLIDWORKS formats. No broken filaments since installing so here's hoping that continues.

Obviously printed on my Lulzbot TAZ 4 in PolyMAX from PolyMakr (specialty PLA with great strength and flexibility characteristics. Given the small size, and the expected stress on the part, I printed at .1mm layers, 3 shells, 35% infill. UPDATE
Revised version printed in PLA. Given the original broke. I increased the infill to 60% for the new print.
The Stag of House Baratheon - Game of Thrones
A handy piece of eye occluder and pin hole for eye examination.  Use the pin hole when a patient has forgotten to bring his or her glasses, that way you will get a near enough correct visual acuity.
Just load the STL files and it will be ready for printing.  No brim needed.

Scrolly is an open-source scroll!
.Use it to jot down notes without the clutter of notes
it uses two manual handles to scoll forward/backward. The deisgn is part 3D-printed and part laser cut in plywood. Future upgrdes may include - motorized scrolling, an integrated scanner, and a movable pen or thermal printer for ink-based digital signage. scrolly uses standard 80mm thermal paper rolls
The design was made using Onshape and is fully public and configurable. grab - the file at - https://cad.onshape.com/documents/4ad58d9a4088415b9e0dbf18/w/d21452802d11465e93e2b60f/e/c2cd05ed931f4cf5a88d1cab video - https://youtu.be/ZnE1YC8N7sY

*all the wooden pieces are laser cut on 5.5mm wood. *i suggest not printing the inner tube and roller due to the fact that the z-resolution layers will increase friction, instead find plastic tubes that can be cut with a saw (use the stl's measurements to get the size right). *use standard 80mm thermal paper rolls.
the rolls include a plastic tube inside them-using a small file cut-out/remove material so as to create a "negative-tooth" into witch the small tooth on both the gear holder and back cap can be inserted (this will increase the force applied so that the roll will turn), keep the teeth one across from another. assembly can be found at https://cad.onshape.com/documents/4ad58d9a4088415b9e0dbf18/w/d21452802d11465e93e2b60f/e/c2cd05ed931f4cf5a88d1cab

Last week I went to the car wash but forgot to take of my radio antenna. so it broke down. The socked for the antenna was M5 thread so I thought lets try making my own antenna. I bought a meter of M5 threaded rod and divided it in 4 pieces, (so I had some spare-parts for when it happens again) when I connected it to the socked my radio worked great again, it only looked crap. so i thought lets make something i can screw over the M5-rod. next thing i did: I made a pipe(inner diameter 4.6mm outer diameter 5.4mm in solidworks and tryed experimenting with slic3rs spiral vase settings, after some experimenting I finally found the right settings to make the female M5 thread to fit over my rod. Settings I used: Nozzle size: 0.8 (mine is just 0.4 but otherwise I cant make a layer thickness of 0.75)
Layer thickness : 0.75
speed: very low (7mm/s)
perimeters: 1
fan speed: a constant 70% material settings:
filament diameter: 1.75
then I set the extrusion multiplier on 2.21 because i needed atleast dubbel the amount of material because of the layer thinkness and width i wanted. after that i needed to scale the object so it would fit my M5 threaded rod, so in the end I scaled the object to 144% normal size.
result> "Female" M5 threaded-rod
I also tryed printing the "male M5 threaded-rod by scaling my pipe down to 61% and worked great aswell. Hope this is Usefull to someone ^^

title: Lulzbot Mini UDOO Mounting Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Little bracket to mount a UDOO (this is a Quad) on the side of the Lulzbot Mini. // I use the UDOO to run OctoPrint Required:
5x Nylon M3x9 screws
8x Nylon M3 nuts
M3 Tapping tool Instructions:
1- Tap all 4 holes (the center one doesn't need it) 2- Screw bracket on with a M3 nylon screw to the M3 hole on the side of the printer (mine had a screw missing, i'm not sure if it's supposed to be that way, but in any case remove the screw if needed - it just holds the PSU in place) 3- place 4 screws in the UDOO, at the right place and screw on 2 nuts, not too tight to prevent the screw from turning. (these act as spacers) 4- screw the 4 screws to the bracket, the PSU Connector should face the back of the printer.

comments.text: Maker beware of ATF. I have a determination letter from their firearms technology branch for a paintball silencer that was intended to be 3D printed (just like this one) and was told they will consider it a real silencer and that manufacture and possession without the proper paperwork (form 1 or 4) is a felony.   I was told the only way it would be exempted from this regulation was if it was permanently attached to the host paintball marker.
comments.author: naporter

comments.text: This particular device is not capable of being filled with foam or other sound deadening material. Additionally, the barrel portion is not ported, and provides no way of reducing the expansion of gasses if they were to enter. As such it does not reduce the decibel report of a weapon and therefore is not considered a silencer under ATF rulings. This model is purely a decorative item. If you would like more information please refer to https://www.atf.gov/files/regulations-rulings/rulings/atf-rulings/atf-ruling-2005-4.pdf
comments.author: naporter

title: The Luce Chapel 東海大學 路思義教堂

description.text: The Luce Memorial Chapel (Chinese: 路思義教堂) is a Christian chapel on the campus of Tunghai University in Taichung, Taiwan. It was designed by the firm of noted architect I. M. Pei(Chinese: 貝聿銘), who was also responsible for the master plan and the early development of the campus of Tunghai University, with likely participation by architects Chi-kuan Chen(Chinese: 陳其寬) and Chao-kang Chang(Chinese: 張肇康). The chapel was named in honor of the Rev. Henry W. Luce, an American missionary in China in the late 19th century and father of publisher Henry R. Luce. The project was originally planned in April 1954 but put on hold until July 1960. Construction took place from September 1962 until November 1963. Construction costs totaled 125,000 USD.[1] The chapel is located on a 3-acre zone in the center of campus, and is set on an irregular hexagonal base, providing 477 m² of gross floor area, including the 245 m² nave (with 500 seats), 81 m² chancel, and 44 m² robing rooms. The church itself is a tent-like conoid structure, with four warped leaves rising to 19.2 m high, establishing itself as a central landmark on campus. The chapel was first conceived as a multi-planar, wooden structure, but the architects soon abandoned the idea of using wood due both to the humid environment and to seismic concerns. The form of four curved surfaces built with reinforced concrete was likely influenced by the design of the Philips Pavilion, designed by renown architect Le Corbusier for the Brussels World’s Fair (known as Expo 58) in 1958. However, unlike the Philips Pavilion and other contemporary ruled-surface buildings of the era, Luce Chapel is not a thin-shell structure. The chapel’s planes are composed of lattice beams that gradually grow thicker as they descend. The structural concept might be influenced by that of the Yale University Art Gallery, completed in 1953 and designed by Louis Kahn, another noted architect of the time. The exterior of the Chapel is covered with yellow, glazed, diamond-shaped tiles echoing the diamond-shaped coffer beams on the building’s interior. The Chapel’s elaborate reinforced concrete formwork was created by local craftsmen. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luce_Memorial_Chapel

description.text: This is a holster for my Flip Video Camera I made. (Got it printed at Ponoko.com) I always hated carrying my flip camera around in my pocket so this was born... It has a belt clip on the back to clip it on your pocket or whatever. It also protects the buttons so you don't accidentally turn it on while carrying it. Too bad Cisco is discontinuing it... :( I used my mock-up of the flip camera to make the holster. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7470 It turned out pretty good! :D There are two STLs for printing: High Res and Low Res. Pretty self explanatory. Mind the Inventor file... It is kind of messy.. :P

• Print
  • Insert Flip Ultra HD Camera
  • Clip on pocket
  • Enjoy!
    • You will need to re-orientate or turn on supports to print this on a MakerBot or the like.
Roll up your earphones so they don't get tangled.

author: sweetpickles

remixed_from.author: TorchRed77Vette
remixed_from.title: Auto Level for Folger Prusa i3

title: Mk7 Fan Duct with Auto Level Servo Slot

description.text:
I've taken the Mk7 Fan duct and merged it with the auto level servo bracket. This reduces space and allows the auto level probe to be closer to the hot end while also allowing additional cooling.  
This design is specifically for the Folger Tech Prusa I3.

I've printed this with 0.2mm resolution.
I had to remove the mount brackets from the SG90 servo and glue the servo in. Also used a dremel to cut a small slot for the servo wires.

comments.text: First of all, I love this design! BUT I just worry that not enough air will get through to cool the heatsinks, since the servo blocks half of it. have you had any extruder issues such as jamming?
comments.author: Randman77

comments.text: When the fan is running I notice the heatsink is cool to the touch, so I don't think the servo is really blocking that much air. My thought process is that most the air will just go around the servo since it is a chambered system. (could be wrong)
comments.author: Randman77

comments.text: Thanks for your reply. I think you are right about it being a closed system, which should force the air out. I will be testing it out very soon.
comments.author: ShinningBob

comments.text: I have the same printer as you.  Do you have your fan set to always on or are you using the auto cooling function?
comments.author: CrankyCoder

comments.text: I have it set to always on as it's the only cooling for the hot head. Seems like things go bad when the overall heat of the head assembly gets to high. I think it leads to extruder jams. I'm new to 3D printing myself, so I assume that is the correct thing to do.
comments.author: CrankyCoder

comments.text: do you recall what length screws you had to get for this?   and what thread for that matter?
comments.author: ShinningBob

comments.text: I took the original screws that attached the fan to the assembly and used them to attach the duct to the assembly. I then used short screws M3 8mm I think to attach the fan to the duct.
comments.author: CrankyCoder

comments.text: I totally understand being new.  I have only a couple prints under my belt.  I was getting jams on a regular basis before really kicking up the cooling.   So I figured i would ask.  I just had abs delivered today so I will be printing this soon, may adjust it for a bigger fan but this is definitely coming :)
comments.author: ShinningBob

comments.text: Cool Design.  How much air flow are you getting out the duct?
comments.author: TorchRed77Vette

comments.text: The design splits off about 20% of the air flow. I'm not sure how much difference this will make on printing as apposed to a dedicated fan. My goal was to utilize the existing hardware of the kit (plus the servo) and to get the probe closer to the print head.
comments.author: TorchRed77Vette

author: ballerin

title: OpenScad Quadcopter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A printable design for a quadcopter with the openscad design file for
you to tweak or change to suit your parts or required size/shape etc.
Of note is the fact that the controller board and camera platform are
isolated from vibration by being mounted on the battery platform which
is attached by 6 anti-vibration balls. The weight (inertia) of the battery
keeps the controller board and camera free from vibration - no
rolling-shutter effect or jittery controller even with unbalanced props.

I have added a list of the parts I have used to complete this quad in
the files section. These are only a suggestion (that I know work),
but many substitutions are possible. All up weight (including battery & FPV) is 1.5kg Print parts 1 to 6. You need to print part 4 4 time (the arms)
You have the choice of printing the arms as
complete units with legs (print part 4) or printing the legs and arms
separately (print parts 4a and 4b). If printed separately, the legs are
in two halves that glue together and then glue to the arm (this
arrangement is stronger than the leg & arm printed together).
I printed with ABS and use acetone to glue together. To complete the frame you will need 6 anti-vibration balls (strong
enough to hold the battery weight between them), 8 40mm M3 bolts,
12 12mm M3 bolts and associated nylock nuts & washers, and 16
10mm M3 bolts for the motor mounts. Obviously all the usual quad parts are needed to complete the
model - motors, props, ESCs, controller, power distribution board,
R/C receiver and battery, and optional camera, FPV transmitter,
GPS etc. The design as given is to fit a MultiWii PRO flight controller, but
other controllers can be accommodated by changing the OpenScad
parameters. If you want to tweak the design, there are plenty of
comments in the OpenScad file to guide you. It is particularly easy
to change the motor mounting hole positions to suit different
motors. There seems to be no standard as to where the wires come out of the motors - you can change the orientation to get the wires to
come out along the arm. The controller lid is optional, and is used
to shield the barosensor on the controller from air currents and
light. Arms are an OpenScad derivative of the arms in the "Crossfire2"
design by MickyB.

Using the following options: right_initial = R
left_initial = M
heart_size = 20
your_font = write/Letters.dxf

So what do you get when you combined a Spoon, a Fork and a Knife? You get a Sporknife! This is your one stop utensil for taking down anything the fridge can throw at you... I modeled this off of a cheap sporknife thing I found at a dollar store.. The model itself is pretty complex, I would say... Multiple planes with bends in one plane, two different ways, etc.. It was fun to recreate though! :D There are two STLs for printing: High Res and Low Res. Pretty self explanatory. Once again, the Inventor file is kind of messy.. I really need to start cleaning those up after I'm done.. This was printed at Ponoko.com

• Print
  • Pick up Sporknife
  • Grab random food object
  • Eat random food object with said Sporknife
  • Repeat until satisfied.
    • You will need to re-orientate or turn on supports to print this on a MakerBot or the like.

description.text: I designed a kaleidocycle using six pseudo-tetrahedra. The hinges are "snap joints". See the video: http://youtu.be/Qxe9ZNujcss

PRINT:
(3) "A"
(3) "B" The arrows must be pointing UP when orientating for slicing. These are not symmetrical. Connect "A" to "B". Designed to print without support structures. I sliced at 0.1 mm layer height, 4 mm wall, 100% fill. The actual wall thickness of the object is 1.2 mm. Printed at between 90 mm/s and 125 mm/s on my Ultimaker and sliced with Cura. Printed with PLA. Assembling can be tricky. It is helpful to "press-stress" the hinges by moving them back-and-forth with your fingers first to make them more flexible. Make certain you have the "A" and "B" aligned properly (not one hinge off) and both arrows are pointing in the same direction. Start the hinge sort of like a zipper. You cannot snap all of the hinge joints at once. Start at an outside edge and work toward the opposite side. I found it easier to insert one set of hinge "dimples" behind the opposite side (sort of like an interlocking comb) and then wiggle back-and-forth until the outside dimple moves into position and the continue wiggling until the rest pop into place. I will plan to upload another model with fewer hinge connections to make this part easier. At first, it doesn't seem like it will work, but after you figure out the technique, it should not take longer than one minute per hinge joint. Enjoy!
